Problem:
Consider a function \\( z(t) = e^{i \\omega t} \\), representing a complex oscillation on the unit circle in the complex plane. We analyze the impact of the Laplace transformation \\( \\mathcal{L} \\), defined for any function \\( g(t) \\) by \\( \\mathcal{L}(g(t)) = \\int_0^\\infty e^{-st}g(t) dt \\), where \\( s \\) is a complex number.

If an intervention involves scaling \\( z(t) \\) by a factor \\( a \\) (where \\( a \\) is a real number) at some time \\( t_0 \\), will the Laplace transform of the new function always yield a real positive value for the real part of \\( s \\) being large?
Explanation: The scaling intervention on the function \\( z(t) \\) modifies the function to \\( a e^{i \\omega t} \\). The Laplace transform of this scaled version, for large values of the real part of \\( s \\), tends to zero due to the exponential term \\( e^{-st} \\) dominating, hence the real part of the transform approaches zero, which is non-negative.
